I recommend Beat Hazard. Have a love for music, violence, and bright flashing lights? This game combines exactly those three things into a jam-packed seisure-ific fun time! The best part of it all, is that you can use your own tunes to fuel the carnage! You've gotta try this game.

Beat Hazard is a top down dual stick arcade shooter similar to the classic game Asteroid, but on neon colored steroids. Its pretty much contained in a single screen and the game throws waves of asteroids, ships and space worms after you. Since its a dual stick shooter, the controls are easy, left stick to move, right stick to fire the direction you're aiming. There are also bombs to clear the screen when it gets completely full of enemies.   Beat Hazard has a major twist. Your rate of fire is controlled by the tempo or beats per minute of the music. Not just your bullets but the enemy speed too. If you don't care for the songs that the game comes with, you can play one of your own .mp3s or listen to Internet radio. The neon laser beams make the game come to life as more than a game. It could be a visualizer for your mp3 playlist.  Every song is a level. When the song ends or your lives run out, you see your high score and the game remembers how far you got and your high score. So you can play it again for a better high score or to go further in the song. I'd much rather have the game go from song to song than force me to start up a new game for the next song. There is a survival mode that will keep going song to song, but its just a single life.  The enemy diversity shines through in the game. There are simple ships that fly in long waves. Larger ships that take more damage. Even larger ships that explode into a hail of homing missiles. Still other ships have dual repulsor beams to push you around. Magnetic ships have dual rays that pull you in. There are segmented space worms, easier to defeat neon worms. It is a varitable feast. Not just that, but diverse bosses. Everything from huge space ships, gigantic worms to star fish that coil up their tentacles for protection. These enemies will fill your screen in no time especially on the upper three difficulties. The game has a way to keep your mind engaged as to how you can survive.  Every score that you have go to your level or rank. The score is like experience. You will rank up and get to unlock a perk. You need to buy the perk once its been unlocked. Not just buy it, but buy multiples of it. Then equip it. There are perks that give you extra lives, extra bombs, and increase score multipliers. Other things that can get unlocked are extra difficulty modes for when 'hardcore' gets too easy for you.  There are other layers of complexity to the Beat Hazard such as a risk reward system. If you don't shoot a set amount of time your score multiplier goes up. If you survive long enough without dying, the multiplier goes up again. Before you know it you're at 45+ of a score multiplier if not 100+ with perks. All the while enemies will drop things for you to pickup such as extra multipliers, money, bombs to use, power ups for your laser and volume increases. Its very risk or reward. Do you leave your safe corner of the screen, navigate through the madness to get your $10?  The game is kind enough that when you die, it litters the area with items to get you back up and competing again. That is a downfall of other games that if you die late into a game, your underpowered ship is useless against the high difficulty enemies.  If you get lonely there is 2 player and online multiplayer where you compete on a single screen against someone. Not just that, but the game will notify you if someone is trying to multiplayer at that time. You can interrupt your own game to play against someone. This ensures there's always someone to play.  I say this game is well worth the $10 asking price.

'Beat Hazard Ultra' - Review  Gameplay: 6/10 A fun game. Modern effects meets old skool arcade gameplay. If Galaga was invented today this game would be it. If you're a fan of the acrade syle or want a bit of nostalgia with a modern twist, then this game is for you. The basic idea on which the gameplay is based doesn't change, but the in-game options, level ups, currency and extras add a little variety to mix it all up nicely enough to entertain. Initially the gameplay feels tricky if not strange and unintuitive, however over time it becomes a bit more like second nature rather than stressful frustration.  Game ambiance: n/a  Reliability/Stability: 10/10 No crash or instability issues to report.  Story/Plot: n/a  Concept: 7/10 Arcade style games like this have been available since the 70's. To think that a new one can be created today, so successfully, is almost astonishing. The classic arcade space-themed gameplay is offset with the original idea of not only incorporating your own music playlist, but having the game react and respond to the music. This certainly brings a fun new perspective to this genre.  Concept execution: 7/10 With many features such as multilayer online co-op gameplay with friends, perks, power-up's and a variety of single player modes, this game will keep you busy for a while. Or at least, as lite fun goes, it'll entertain you enough until you decide which major title you want to play next.   Textures: 5/10 Generally speaking the textures in Beat Hazard are average for a game, but not underdeveloped. You could say they are just enough and nothing more. This can be forgiven however as the focus of this game is more about beat triggered special effects and skill rather than mind blowing textures.   Modelling: 5/10 Again, the modelling isn't necessarily the main aspect of this game, and again like the textures, it is just enough. They are enough to allow the game experience to be enjoyable and that's the whole point.  Graphics: 8/10 The special effects in this game are dizzying, strobing and seizure inducing. Glorious if you like it, hideous if you don't. Either way you can't deny it's extremely colorful and eye -twitchingly pretty. Turn the room lights off, the screen brightness up and strap yourself into your favorite spaceship!  Sound: 6/10 The sound isn't too bad, given the premise of this game revolves around music. It's what you'd expect from an arcade game but with a more modern production quality. Love it or hate it the volumetric and situational dynamics are there, perhaps a little overdone and exaggerated, but then it does have to stand side-by-side with the huge visuals. If you enjoy shooting spaceships with big audible bangs and explosions then you'll defiantly have fun here.   Music: 10/10 I have to give this 10/10 for music because it's comprised from my personally playlist. You will too unless you couldn't care less about music, in which case this game might not be to your taste.  Adjustable shadow mapping: No Bonus/Extras: none

Alongside gaming skyscrapers like Crysis or Counter-Strike, it's the tiny pizza stall in between where you go from time to time - like, casually. You feel the need, the motivation to just play a round of it, from time to time - not for long, just a few good tracks, and that's it. Until your next visit, in a few days.  Besides, Beat Hazard has developed (or has been developed) continously. It started as the basic game and received two major updates, both the two boosting the game's variability and extent, giving it new game modes, bosses, enemies and the ability of creating own ships (Shadow Operations Unit DLC). And while it was growing, it never lost its easy-to-learn usability.  Everyone interested in music should give this a try - it doesnt matter if you're going casual in this or seek a challenge for there are lots of leaderboards to improve on. Two recommendations are posted here, one for the Shadow OPs DLC and my original one for the Beat Hazard Ultra.  Shadow Operations recommendation (18 Apr 2014):  A very fun DLC that lets you create your own ships, upload the ships to the workshop, and download other player's ships from the workshop. When creating your ship, you can choose from several attributes such as the ship's size, how fast/slow it accelerates, top speed, how fast/slow it decelerates, how strong the bullets are, how fast the bullets move, position of the guns, whether or not you repel or attract perks, how many beams (1-3), and more. You also get to set up to three missions for your creation so you can make them easy, hard, or a mix. As you gain higher ranks, you unlock some nice cosmetic attributes such as flares and engine thrust colour. It really is a lot of fun and it gives you new ways to enjoy Beat Hazard.  Any song with the Shadow OPs icon next to it has a chance to spawn what you need for missions. Additional info from a quote from Starg: 'The 'play random track' and 'one I've not played before' will also automatically choose a song that fits the current mission criteria.' It's been on my wishlist for a while and it was gifted to me recently - and unfortunately it's a lot less fun than I'd imagined it to be! I'm biased for these kinds of games since I like challenging arcade games and music-powered games, so you'd think I'd like this one. Yes, well... not really.  (Mind you, I'm in no way photosensitive like some others who have left a negative review on this game have been, and I can handle rapid flashing just fine, but if it becomes gameplay-inhibiting, then the design is absolutely flawed.)  Problems with the game: * Often screen-filling visual effects that prevent you from seeing what is going on. You can't dodge bullets if you can't see them... * Overboard on the 'flashy sparkly fireworks' effects. I mean, way overboard, and then some. It's not 'cool', it's not 'attractive', and it gives you a headache if you're not careful. * The music plays very soft. I have properly balanced music files and they simply don't play at a decent volume in the game - for a music-focused game you'd expect the audio component to be at least adequate and give priority to proper playback without having to amplify it into clipping ranges. * Scoring is meaningless: levels are random, so what rewards you get and points you score for a song is not dependent on the music at all. Score is determined by chance and not by skill, as a result. * Music-based firepower will favor even, loud songs. You get a dynamic song with breaks and softer parts and you're pretty much at the mercy of whatever random fleets of ships are thrown your way with no way to fight them off. And woe if you hit a quiet spot when a boss is thrown at you. Good luck with that, get ready for a grind. * Screen-filling visual effects that.. Ohwait, I already said that. :P Yes, it's a problem. Worthy of mentioning twice. It kills the ability to properly play a 'bullet hell' game. Period.

Beat Hazard is instead an isometric space/arena shooter that paces everything, from the intensity of your fire to the pacing of enemies to the seizure-inducing screen effects, to the intensity of your music.  It's a pleasant game for when you want to zone out and enjoy sound and color. There's not a lot there, but it's a pleasant enough game. Beat Hazard is a unique shoot'em up. The levels are the songs on your computer. How does it work though? When you start playing, you don't really see how it goes at the rythm of your songs. But after some time playing, you'll start to realize that it really does go at the rythm of your songs. It's hard to notice though, since Beat Hazard require quite a lot of focus on the ennemies and incoming projectiles. Despite that, Beat Hazard is a hardcore and very addicting game. If you love shooters, this is an excellent game for you.  HOWEVER, I do have to give some warnings. DO NOT BUY IF YOU SUFFER FROM EPILIPSY. This game has A LOT of flashing lights and effects. And when I say a lot, I really do mean a lot.   If you do not suffer from epilipsy, please, take breaks after an hour of play. I know, I sound like someone who says you should take break after an hour of playing video games, but no. Beat Hazard is a special case. After playing for like 1 hour, I started to have an headache, and plus, my eyes started to feel tired. And I'm not making this up. So please, if you're going to play this excellent game, take care of yourself, and take a break after an hour of consecutive play.    Overall, you should buy this game. I highly recommend it. I also recommend that you play with a controller. ;)
